ygData.subject: Re: [neat] wanting to code...
ygData.msgSnippet: Yes, doing your own implementation from scratch would give you some good insights into the algorithm.  But it s a heck of a lot of work. ... to just have

Yes, doing your own implementation from scratch would give you some
good in=
sights into the algorithm.  But it's a heck of a lot of work.
:)  And there=
 are already some very good implementations of NEAT ready
to just have fitn=
ess functions coded for them.

I'd like to make another pitch for ANJI, sin=
ce we're planning on doing
another release very soon (within the next 2-3 w=
eeks).  If you haven't
visited the site, have a look, and at least browse t=
hrough the
javadocs:

http://anji.sourceforge.net/index.html

As Colin ment=
ioned, it's nice to have an IDE, and we use Eclipse,
which is well-supporte=
d and very powerful.

Anyway, the upcoming release will have all the double=
 pole balancing
experiments, as well as all of our active vision stuff.

De=
rek

On 7/13/05, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> Ian Badcoe wro=
te:
> 
> >Hi,
> >       Is there any advice people have to offer if I'm goi=
ng to start some
> >serious NEAT coding?
> >
> >
> >       I want to work i=
n C++ on Windows, but I'll probably want to stay away from
> >platform spec=
ific issues like user interfaces and graphics output, so I'm
> >pretty conf=
ident I can keep away from nasty build problems and suchlike
> >arising fro=
m those.
> >
> >
> Ok I'm going to put in my 2cents worth on  Java/.Net  no=
w so some may
> want to tune to another station for 5 mins :)
> 
> A few ke=
y points then:
> 1) C++, Java and C# are syntactially almost identical. If =
you can code
> in C++ you can do the other two. C# even has pointers.
> 
> =
2) Nasty build problems are largely elminated by Java/.Net - if you get
> t=
he correct JDK/framework version you're almost there. In fact with
> SharpN=
EAT there are no external dependencies outside of the cour
> library. I'm n=
ot 100% sure if this is true of the Java NEATs, but I
> don't recall having=
 any problem building ANJI a while back.
> 
> 3) .Net is language agnostic =
and there exist, amongst many others,
> compilers for Java, C++ and C# that=
 target the .Net CLR (The equivalent
> of the Java Virtual Machine). Classe=
s can be definend in one language,
> sub-classed in another and instantiate=
d in yet another, it's so easy I
> felt like crying when I first used it, s=
urely it must be a trick? :)
> 
> So you could write an experiment in C++ a=
nd plug it into SharpNEAT. On
> the other hand with a few minor syntactic a=
lterations your C++ will
> compile as Java and you can plug it into ANJI - =
obviously how you attach
> an experiment to our frameworks differs a bit, b=
ut not by much I would
> expect.
> 
> >       My coding style tends towards=
 object-based approaches, templated
> >utilities, small classes, inheritanc=
e only for clearly defined interfaces,
> >STL containers (but not generally=
 streams), lots of asserts and code
> >designed to crash rather than vaguel=
y paper over errors....
> >
> >
> Java has an assert keyword, .Net just has=
 a Debug.Assert method in the
> framework. But since they run in managed ru=
ntime environments you won't
> get any nasty pointer errors, corruption of =
memory or anything like that
> anyway.
> 
> > OTOH, I would be quite happy =
to start with a written
> >specification and write it myself.  I find this =
is usually the fastest way
> >to get into understanding all the dirty detai=
ls...
> >
> >
> Yeh, absolutely agree there.
> 
> >       What do people re=
commend?
> >
> >
> Well obviously I'm biased so all I will say is that if y=
ou do want to
> try out SharpNEAT then all you need is the SDK from microso=
ft (free
> download). On top of that you really want a nice IDE and SharpDe=
velop
> should do nicely there(again, free) - it has support for C++ coding=
 as
> well as C# and others. The only other issue is that there has been
> =
another code re-org since the version on sourceforge and I've been
> handin=
g out versions to people as and when requested until I get round
> to doing=
 a proper release. The re-org was specifically done to support
> co-ev expe=
riments!
> 
> For ANJI you need the Java SDK (free!) and for a free IDE I w=
ould
> suggest IBM Eclipse. Actually Eclipse has support for and is integra=
ted
> with all kinds of systems these days, e.g. I strongly suspect you cou=
ld
> use it for developing in C++ and C# as well.
> 
> Colin
>
